title: Worth a look
review: Situated in the place of commons in the Agra Fort. This tomb is very interesting and intricate. Definitely recommend a guide or audio guide to be able to appreciate the history of this area of the fort and the history of the tomb.

title: Tomb of British Governer of this region in India
review: This tomb is of John Russell, who was the British governor of this region of India. It is located just outside the Diwan-I-Aam complex in Agra Fort and worth a quick short stop.

title: open grave with some decoration in stone
review: This tomb is situated on the south side of the Diwan-i-Am. It is an open grave with some decoration in stone.It is said that during the First War of Independence on July 5,1857 the British troops suffered heavy loss at Agra because of the aggressive attack of the Indian Freedom Fighters. Lord Colvin who had taken shelter in the Agra Fort died of cholera in the central room of the Shah Jahani Mahal.This tomb is testimony to the landmark uprising and mutiny against the British in India during this time.

title: Tomb
review: This tomb is located in Agra red fort and the tomb is well maintained and this tomb is of Britisher.

title: It's a tomb!
review: Tomb of one of the British, prominently placed in the centre of the fort. Ok but nothing special in itself. Nice surroundings.

title: British governor’s tomb in Agra Fort
review: It seemed slightly incongruous to find the tomb of a foreigner in an Indian fort, especially as he was lieutenant-governor of the North-West Provinces of British India during the Indian rebellion of 1857, but apparently it was his dying (from cholera) wish at the height of the uprising.

title: Understandably controversial
review: That this very high ranking representative of the British Raj during the Indian Rebellion of 1857 rests in this conspicuous place is a sore point with some Indians. However it is a tribute to their forgiving attitude that the tomb has been left untouched. Also, Colvin was not too hard-fisted and was even accused by higher authorities for showing too much clemency in a proclamation to the "natives" which was therefore censured.
